subject: history
title: Economic Policies & Acts (1858-1885)
description: Major economic policies, fiscal measures, and their impact on Indian economy

rows.description: Introduction of paper currency in India
rows.impact: Unified currency system; facilitated trade; but benefited British trade more

points: First paper currency issued by Government
Backed by gold and silver reserves
details.impact: Modern banking and currency system foundation laid

rows.description: First income tax imposed by James Wilson
rows.impact: Heavy burden on middle class; revenue for British treasury

points: Applied to incomes above Rs. 200 per year
Rate: 2% on incomes Rs. 200-500, up to 8% on higher incomes
details.impact: Indians paid for cost of suppressing their own revolt

rows.description: Railway network expanded from 288 to 14,500 miles
rows.impact: Facilitated British trade and troop movement; some benefit to Indian trade

points: Guaranteed interest system: 5% return to British investors
Employed British engineers and imported British materials
Connected ports to interior (drain of resources)
Some positive: market integration, mobility, employment
details.impact: Served British commercial and military interests primarily; drain of Indian wealth

rows.impact: Improved communication for British administration and trade

points: Later benefited Indian business and society
details.impact: Modernized communication but primarily for British benefit

rows.description: Import duties on British goods gradually abolished
rows.impact: Destroyed Indian industries; flooding of British manufactured goods

points: Import duties on British textiles reduced progressively
Free trade policy benefited British manufacturers
India became dumping ground for British goods
Excise duties imposed on Indian goods to favor imports
details.impact: Deindustrialization of India; millions of artisans unemployed

rows.description: Excise duties on Indian cotton to protect Manchester
rows.impact: Indian cotton industry handicapped to favor British imports

points: Import duty on British cotton abolished
Excise duty imposed on Indian mill-made cloth
Real purpose: protect Manchester textile industry
details.impact: Clear case of subordination of Indian interests to British

rows.description: Forced indigo cultivation and peasant resistance
rows.impact: Peasant exploitation exposed; beginning of agrarian movements

points: European planters forced peasants to grow indigo
Low prices, advances at high interest
Led to decline of indigo cultivation
details.impact: First organized peasant resistance in modern era; exposed colonial exploitation

rows.impact: Heavy revenue burden; peasant indebtedness increased

points: No major change in land revenue policy
Revenue demand remained high (50-60% of produce)
Ryotwari made peasants deal with government directly
Rigid collection regardless of harvest quality

rows.impact: 5-10 million deaths; exposed British neglect of Indian welfare

points: Affected South and West India severely
Lord Lytton refused to stop grain exports
Organized Delhi Durbar instead of relief (1877)
Proclaimed Queen Victoria as Empress of India during famine
details.impact: Exposed British priorities; drain of resources even during famine

rows.description: Inquiry into famine causes and relief measures

points: Set up by Lord Ripon after 1876-78 famine
Identified heavy land revenue as cause
Recommended: railway expansion, irrigation, forest conservation
But didn't address root cause: drain of wealth
details.impact: Acknowledged problem but British unwilling to change exploitative system

rows.description: Government control over forests; tribals displaced
rows.impact: Traditional forest rights curtailed; tribal economy destroyed

points: Reserved forests: no access without permission
Forests exploited for British needs (timber, railways)
details.impact: Alienation of forest-dwelling communities; ecological exploitation

rows.description: Shift from food crops to cash crops
rows.impact: Food security compromised; vulnerability to market fluctuations

points: Peasants forced/induced to grow: cotton, jute, indigo, opium, tea
For export to Britain and world market
Made farmers vulnerable to price fluctuations
Famines became more frequent and severe
details.impact: Food insecurity; greater exploitation; famines intensified

rows.description: Continuous transfer of wealth from India to Britain
rows.impact: India's poverty and Britain's prosperity were interconnected

points: Home charges: payments to British government
Salaries and pensions of British officials
Interest on loans taken for India
Cost of British Army in India
Payments for stores purchased in Britain
Dadabhai Naoroji estimated Â£30-40 million annual drain
details.impact: India impoverished; wealth transfer enriched Britain

rows.description: India used to produce opium for Chinese market
rows.impact: Large revenue for British; Indian land used for drug production

points: Opium grown in Bihar and Malwa
Exported to China despite Chinese opposition
Major source of revenue for British India government
Best agricultural land used for opium, not food
Peasants forced to grow at low prices
details.impact: Indian resources used for immoral drug trade; contributed to China's suffering

data.summary: The period 1858-1885 saw systematic economic exploitation of India through: drain of wealth, deindustrialization, heavy taxation, commercialization of agriculture, and infrastructure built primarily for British interests. While some modern infrastructure was created, the overall impact was impoverishment of India and enrichment of Britain. Economic nationalism began emerging in response to visible exploitation.
